description: {"blocks":[{"key":"80dbr","text":"This protocol describes an alternative way of analyzing SPIRO images for root growth of plants that are transferred to the treatment plates - and thus not imaged from the germination onwards. This protocol combines SPIRO tools, SmartRoot and BackTracker script, as well as R-scripts for data curation. The protocol was thus far tested on Arabidopsis roots - and we intend to test it in the future on tomato roots as well.  ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

groups.title: Stress Architecture and RNA Biology Lab BTI

status.info: We use this protocol and it’s working

steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"5b5v0","text":"Collect your images caputred by SPIRO from the Raspberry Pi by going into the FileManager - and downloading your experiment:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bi3nu","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bv299","text":"  ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"8plk2","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"image","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"91F4A100A86E11EC98C2F97E399E1CE0","height":497,"id":220190,"is_video":false,"legend":"","mime":"image/png","nestedSelector":null,"original_name":"Screen Shot 2022-03-18 at 13.26.37.png","placeholder":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/gzbag3kw.jpg","shadow":false,"source":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/gza8g3kw.jpg","webp_placeholder":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/gza9g3kw.webp","webp_source":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/gza7g3kw.webp","width":550}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"2akg8","text":"Pre-process your images for drifting using the SPIRO pre-process in ImageJ / Fiji - as described on SPIRO Assay github page here. This will result in all of your images being cropped and ALIGNED, and also transferred as multiple layers into one TIFF file. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":124,"length":4}],"data":{}},{"key":"fm04b","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cmci4","text":"  ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"3bh5l","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"link","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"E973C4B0A86E11EC98C2F97E399E1CE0","url":"https://github.com/jiaxuanleong/SPIRO.Assays"}},"1":{"type":"image","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"22642F30A86F11EC98C2F97E399E1CE0","height":419,"id":220194,"is_video":false,"legend":"","mime":"image/png","nestedSelector":null,"original_name":"Screen Shot 2022-03-20 at 12.59.14.png","placeholder":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/gzbeg3kw.jpg","shadow":false,"source":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/gzbcg3kw.jpg","webp_placeholder":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/gzbdg3kw.webp","webp_source":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/gzbbg3kw.webp","width":550}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"6e4os","text":"Now we need to transfer this multi-layer tiff file into individual tif files - preferably containing their timestamp for our future steps.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ehaak","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"epps3","text":"At this  moment - you have two options ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"f6p6e","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fu4uc","text":"1) rather painful (manual) solution that will maintain the information and timestamps in the file name OR ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7gq3m","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"80oit","text":"2) fully automated one - but your images will be renamed into 1, 2, 3, 4 ... and you will loose a timestamp information - if you are confident you will be able to add it back in later in R - go for it - but just beware that this might be a source of potential problems in the future.  ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7qleh","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"44v2g","text":"BUT FIRST - For both options - you need to first invert the image - since SmartRoot prefers the root to be DARKER than the background. Open your mutli-layer tiff in ImageJ/Fiji and select invert function - save the inverted file in your Experiment folder:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"a0f5v","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2ccdj","text":"  ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"9j2ud","text":"now - you can choose whatever option you feel most comfortable with:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6hjoa","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1578s","text":"OPTION 1: manual splitting image using ImageJ/Fiji","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":50}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bnm5a","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"854f","text":"Open the multi-layer-tiff file in Fiji/ImageJ - and select \"Stack to Images\" like on the screenshot below:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1sjki","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"e0e6e","text":" ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"a35gl","text":"It will open ALL layers as individual images and then save individual images through SAVE KEYBOARD SHORTCUT (Mac = cmnd + S; Windows = ctrl + S). It will feel like it takes forever - but its actually not that bad. And also - I really hope to have a more automated solution for this soon. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"jddl","text":" ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"c79b0","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1s0hh","text":"NOTE - make sure to save individual files in ONE FOLDER per plate - similar to the original SPIRO setup.  ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"13elt","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ei45f","text":"As a reference - here is how my folder looks like before I start my SmartRoot part after this option:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2rhf7","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5t5kb","text":"  ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":2,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"7229h","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"carse","text":"OPTION 2: automatic split of the images using ImgMagick","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":55}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"eb3op","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"88q3c","text":"1) Make sure to install ImgMagick on your computer  ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":51,"length":1}],"entityRanges":[{"key":3,"offset":24,"length":9}],"data":{}},{"key":"6aiks","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"14stj","text":"2) Navigate to your folder containing the multi-layered tiff file","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5if8q","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"d3m6h","text":"3) run the following command - {"blocks":[{"key":"n6ap","text":"Trace the LAST file of each plate - containing the longest roots - using SmartRoot plugin for ImageJ / Fiji.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":73,"length":9}],"data":{}},{"key":"d7e4f","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1b3i5","text":"Do NOT put any effort in naming the roots - they will be renamed anyways afterwards - so save your time. We will figure it out what genotype is where later. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"d2b6i","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"f19fu","text":"I advise NOT to trace the roots that are entangled within each other in the last image and/or end in a shoot - they need to be all clearly distinguished roots - not growing into the other root.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"321np","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1vtt","text":"Here is a screenshot of the roots that I did/did not trace on my plate:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"290mv","text":"  ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"link","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"36FCA660A98311EC98C2F97E399E1CE0","url":"https://smartroot.github.io/"}},"1":{"type":"image","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"B3B7F470A98311EC98C2F97E399E1CE0","height":526,"id":220214,"is_video":false,"legend":"","mime":"image/png","nestedSelector":null,"original_name":"Screen Shot 2022-03-21 at 21.59.09.png","placeholder":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/gzb2g3kw.jpg","shadow":false,"source":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/gzbyg3kw.jpg","webp_placeholder":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/gzbzg3kw.webp","webp_source":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/gzbxg3kw.webp","width":550}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"aq9lh","text":"Make sure to install all the dependencies on your computer for BackTracer:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7bocl","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8293f","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"d0a00","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"code_insert","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"d0eq0","text":"scipy ","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"ed5a1","text":"opencv-python ","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"at45p","text":"numpy ","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"76utd","text":"BeautifulSoup ","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"ds343","text":"re ","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"1dftp","text":"XML ","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"1ntl","text":"shutil","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"b0ivp","text":"Once you have everything installed - download the python script from the BackTracker repository, and open it in a code-writing software like Atom.io.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":73,"length":11},{"key":1,"offset":141,"length":7}],"data":{}},{"key":"dclnk","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"e66fv","text":"In the python code - you will need to change TWO things:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"aegkr","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"et3tg","text":"1) adjust the image repository to the folder containing the files with your plate images (and SmartRoot traced the last image - you will get rsml file once the image is traced). ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"vb1p","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ep0gp","text":"  ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":2,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"4ici","text":"2) Make sure to replace all \"tiff\" by \"tif\" - since the BackTracker is using \"tiff\" in their original file format. {"blocks":[{"key":"16gqf","text":"Make a Quality Control - by going into your original Experiment folder - and figuring out if you have any EMPTY RSML files. You can easily see it by the size of the rsml files. As long as the files are NOT empty - it will be fine.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"69v9e","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"dk5o2","text":"You can easily see the size of the files by changing the view in your Finder window:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9tsj4","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"37i11","text":"  ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"dtcdh","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"image","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"D4004940A9EB11EC98C2F97E399E1CE0","height":320,"id":220226,"is_video":false,"legend":"","mime":"image/png","nestedSelector":null,"original_name":"Screen Shot 2022-03-22 at 10.24.36.png","placeholder":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/gzceg3kw.jpg","shadow":false,"source":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/gzccg3kw.jpg","webp_placeholder":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/gzcdg3kw.webp","webp_source":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/gzcbg3kw.webp","width":550}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"sggc","text":"Export your rsml files as csv file one plate as the time through SmartRoot Batch export window:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ac91e","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8avac","text":"  ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"abcn7","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"image","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"F89C7E00A98611EC98C2F97E399E1CE0","height":773,"id":220230,"is_video":false,"legend":"","mime":"image/png","nestedSelector":null,"original_name":"Screen Shot 2022-03-21 at 22.22.20.png","placeholder":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/gzcig3kw.jpg","shadow":false,"source":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/gzcgg3kw.jpg","webp_placeholder":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/gzchg3kw.webp","webp_source":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/gzcfg3kw.webp","width":550}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"8q1fj","text":"The last thing that we need to do in SmartRoot is to figure out what root ID corresponds to your individual genotypes. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ad1sq","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cd1ff","text":"1) Open the penultimate image in your image stack and add tracing data by the BackTracer by selecting with the right click \"Import previous datafile\" - and select the file that was generated by the BackTracker.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"h9ph","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"d7u3t","text":"   ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":1,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"c3u9t","text":"2) Once you imported the automatically traced RSML file - go to RootList on the SmartRoot menu and click \"Refresh\" at the bottom of the root list menu - the root names will appear automatically:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cmnjj","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ao61f","text":"  ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"8i5hi","text":"3) By selecting individual roots - you will be able to tell what root is belonging to what genotype","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4bgoc","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fh30e","text":" make a decoding file - containing the root name as in the rsml file as well as its actual genotype and/or condition - I attach my own decoding file below as an {"blocks":[{"key":"87dfu","text":"Import the data into R and for analysis, you can follow the R-pipeline developed by Magda here. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":90,"length":4}],"data":{}},{"key":"3nlnn","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2gajh","text":"NOTE: There is a big chance there will be MANY outliers / odd time points - so you will spend a significant amount of time in R analysis on data curation.
